results.question: What costs are associated under capital expenditure?
gold_answer: associated with acquiring property, plant and equipment and placing it into service
results.markdown_table_response:
1. Wireless is not included in capital expenditures as it is a purchase of spectrum licences.
2. Cable is not included in capital expenditures as it is a purchase of customer premise equipment.
3. Media is not included in capital expenditures as it is a purchase of media, not a purchase of equipment.
4. Corporate is not included in capital expenditures as it is an investment in IT.
results.csv_string_response:
Capital expenditures include costs associated with acquiring property, plant and equipment and placing it into service. The telecommunications business requires extensive and continual investments, including investment in new technologies and the expansion of capacity and geographical reach. Expenditures related to the acquisition of spectrum licences and additions to right-of-use assets are not included in capital expenditures and do not factor into the calculation of free cash flow or capital intensity. See “Managing Our Liquidity and Financial Resources”, “Key Performance Indicators”, and “Non-GAAP Measures and Related Performance Measures” for more information.
Capital expenditures are significant and have a material impact on our cash flows; therefore, our management teams focus on planning, funding, and managing them. We believe this measure best reflects our cost of property, plant and equipment in a given period and is a simpler measure for comparing between periods.
1 Includes additions to property, plant and equipment net of proceeds on disposition, but does not include expenditures for spectrum licences or additions to right-of-use assets. 2 As defined. See “Key Performance Indicators”.

results.question: How is the fair value of financial instruments that are not traded in active markets determined?
results.markdown_table_response:
To calculate the fair value of financial instruments not traded in an active market, the following valuation techniques are used:
The fair value of interest rate swaps is calculated as the present value of the estimated future cash flows based on observable yield curves.
results.csv_string_response: 3.4 The table below shows the fair value of financial instruments not traded in an active market determined by using valuation techniques.
results.json_rows_response: The Group’s financial instruments not traded in an active market are valued by using valuation techniques to maximise the use of observable market data where it is available. If all significant inputs required for evaluating the fair value of a financial instrument are observable, the instrument is included in level 2. If one or more of the significant inputs are not based on observable market data, the instrument is included in level 3. The specific valuation techniques used to value financial instruments mainly include: • Dealer quotes for similar instruments; • The fair value of interest rate swaps is calculated as the present value of the estimated future cash flows based on observable yield curves; and • Other techniques, such as discounted cash flow analysis, are used to determine fair value for financial instruments.

results.question: How does a non-employee director receive his/her restricted stock unit award or option grant?
gold_answer: on the date of his or her initial appointment to the Board of Directors equal to the pro-rated amount of the annual grant
results.markdown_table_response:
The non-employee director receives a restricted stock unit award or option grant in one of two ways: (1) the non-employee director is appointed as an initial director or a director by a vote of the board of directors or (2) the non-employee director is appointed to the board of directors by the stockholder body. The non-employee director is generally appointed by the board of directors after any annual meeting of stockholders. Additionally, a non-employee director may be appointed to the board of directors by the stockholder body, such as a nominating committee, in order to fill a vacancy or to fill an unexpired term. If the non-employee director is appointed by the board of directors, the stockholder body’s stockholder vote is required. If the non-employee director is appointed by the stockholder body, the stockholder body’s stockholder vote is not required.
The board of directors will usually provide a specific description of the stock award or option grant to the non-employee director. The board of directors will also explain how the stock award or option grant will be calculated and how it will be paid. For more information regarding the stock award or option grant, please refer to the description of our non-employee director compensation
results.csv_string_response: If a non-employee director is initially appointed after an annual meeting of stockholders, his or her restricted stock unit award or option grant will vest on the earlier of the first anniversary of the date of appointment or the next annual meeting of stockholders. A non-employee director’s restricted stock unit award or option grant vest on the earlier of the first anniversary of the date of appointment or the next annual meeting of stockholders, and may be exercisable on the earlier of the tenth anniversary after the date of grant or the termination of the director’s services.
results.json_rows_response: Non-employee directors will receive their restricted stock unit award or option grant in the form of a restricted stock unit award certificate or option grant certificate. For a restricted stock unit award certificate, the recipient will receive the restricted stock unit award on the grant date, and will be required to sign a restricted stock unit award certificate. For an option grant certificate, the recipient will receive an option on the grant date, and will be required to sign an option grant certificate. The recipient may execute the certificate by hand, or by facsimile or email. The restricted stock unit award certificate and option grant certificate are issued by the Company’s Board of Directors. The recipients of restricted stock unit awards and options will be required to execute and deliver the restricted stock unit award certificate or option grant certificate to the Company. The Company will retain the right to inspect the restricted stock unit award certificate or option grant certificate to verify that the recipient has executed and delivered the certificate to the Company. The restricted stock unit award certificates or option grant certificates may be delivered to the Company at any time, including any time prior to or after the initial grant date.

results.question: How is Basic earnings per share, or EPS calculated?
gold_answer: by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period, without consideration for common stock equivalents.
results.markdown_table_response: Basic EPS is calculated by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding. Diluted EPS is calculated by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding and the weighted-average number of dilutive common stock equivalents outstanding.
results.csv_string_response:
The table below presents the computation of basic and diluted earnings per share:
For the years ended December 31, 2019, 2018 and 2017, the Company incurred net losses and accordingly excluded common stock equivalents for outstanding stockbased awards, which represented all potentially dilutive securities, of 2.5 million, 3.7 million, and 4.5 million, respectively, from the calculation of diluted net loss per share due to their anti-dilutive nature.
results.json_rows_response:
Basic EPS is computed by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period, without consideration for common stock equivalents. Diluted EPS is computed by dividing net income by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period and the weighted-average number of dilutive common stock equivalents outstanding for the period determined using the treasury-stock method. For purposes of this calculation, common stock options, restricted stock units and restricted stock awards are considered to be common stock equivalents and are only included in the calculation of diluted EPS when their effect is dilutive. In periods in which the Company has a net loss, dilutive common stock equivalents are excluded from the calculation of diluted EPS.
The table below presents the computation of basic and diluted earnings per share:
For the years ended December 31, 2019, 2018 and 2017, the Company incurred net losses and accordingly excluded common stock equivalents for outstanding stock-based awards, which represented all potentially dilutive securities, of 2.5 million, 3.7 million, and 4.5 million, respectively, from the calculation of diluted net loss per share due to their anti-dilutive nature.

gold_answer: by reducing the carrying amount directly

results.csv_string_response:
In order to write off a receivable, the receivable must be a legal debt. A legal debt is a debt that is:
a) Not subject to any agreement or promise to pay;
b) Subject to a legal right to payment that is enforceable in a court of law;
c) Not based on any statutory right to payment or an agreement to pay by a third party; and
d) Not based on the credit of a third party.
In other words, it must be a legal debt that is enforceable in a court of law. It must also be a debt that is payable in the future, for which a payment has been agreed and is expected to be received in the future.
If a receivable is an uncollectible legal debt, and it is not an impairment allowance, the receivable is written off. The receivable is written off by reducing the carrying amount directly.
A receivable is written off when the Group becomes aware that it is unable to collect all amounts due according to the original terms of the receivable.
